chapter.title: 13 Procedures for the Storage of Microorganisms

sect1.title: 13 Procedures for the Storage of Microorganisms

para.phrase: ROSEMARY C. SHE AND SUSAN M. BUTLER-WU

sect1.para: The long- and short-term preservation of microorganisms for future study has a long tradition in microbiology. As early as the 1880s it was observed that bacteria survived well in ice but that freeze-thaw cycles damaged the cell wall (1). By the 1900s, researchers had optimized methods to preserve tissues, viruses, and bacteria for later use by freeze-drying. It had become apparent to early researchers that preserving microorganisms allowed them to be studied at a later time and to remain viable when transported (2). Indeed, culture collections of microorganisms are valuable resources for scientific research in microbial diversity and evolution, patient management, epidemiological investigations, diagnostic test verification and validation, and educational purposes. Preserved individual strains of microorganisms serve as permanent records of microorganisms’ unique phenotypic profiles and provide the material for further genotypic characterizations. Such reference collections can encompass rare infectious agents unique to an individual or catalog the history of disease caused by common pathogens such as those responsible for community outbreaks.

There are multiple methods for microbial preservation. Effective storage is defined as the ability to maintain an organism in a viable state, free of contamination and without changes in its genotypic or phenotypic characteristics. In addition, the organism must be easily restored to its condition prior to preservation. Microbial preservation methods have been extensively evaluated over the past 60 years, and often, optimal methods for preservation depend on a microorganism’s taxonomic classification. Review articles, monographs, and books have been published that provide detailed information about the storage of various types of microorganisms (3–7). For clinical microbiology laboratories, simple and broadly applied methods are necessary to maintain organisms for short-and long-term recovery. This chapter presents methods that can be used for the storage of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, and viruses.

sect2.title: Direct Transfer to Subculture
sect2.para: The simplest method for maintaining the short-term viability of microorganisms, usually used for bacteria, is periodic subculture to fresh medium. Although it is simple, if a microorganism is saved for >1 week, this method is potentially labor-intensive, requires extensive laboratory space, and may compromise a microorganism’s phenotypic profile. Each transfer to a new subculture increases the likelihood of mutation, with undesirable changes in a microorganism’s characteristics. Furthermore, plasmids may be lost with subculturing.

The interval between transfers varies among organisms. Additionally, the rate of mutation is quite variable. Some organisms appear stable indefinitely with repeated transfer, and others may change phenotypic traits after as few as two or three passages. The actual rate of mutation, however, has not been studied until recently using sequencing technology (8, 9). In Escherichia coli, for example, the rate of mutation is estimated to be ~2.2 per 1010 nucleotides per generation (9). Other issues that must be addressed with direct transfer include the medium to be used, the storage conditions, and the frequency of transfer.

sect3.title: Maintenance Medium
sect3.para: The medium should support the survival of the microorganism but minimize its metabolic processes and slow its rate of growth. Extreme environments should be avoided because microorganisms have the unique ability to adapt through mutation events to survive in suboptimal surroundings. A medium with too high a nutrient content will induce rapid replication that requires more frequent transfers. The optimal medium for maintaining microorganisms has not been clearly defined and most likely varies from one species to another and may even depend on the individual strain. Media that have been used include distilled water, tryptic soy broth, and nutrient broths, all of which may be used with or without cryopreservatives.

sect3.title: Storage Conditions
sect3.para: Many clinical laboratories store organisms, usually bacteria, for short periods on routine agar media at the workbench. Cultures kept in this fashion for prolonged periods are subject to drying. However, the preferred method is to transfer organisms into an agar slant tube (e.g., tryptic soy agar, blood agar, potato dextrose agar) with a screw top and to store them in an organized location away from sunlight and significant temperature changes. To prevent drying, caps can include rubber liners, or film can be wrapped over the top of the tube before or after the cap is screwed on. Storage at lower temperatures (5 to 8°C) slows metabolic processes and maintains viability for longer periods.

sect3.title: Frequency of Transfer
sect3.para: There is no set protocol for the frequency of transfer since storage conditions, media used, and types of microorganisms vary among laboratories. Individual laboratories may conduct studies for each category of microorganism to determine optimal intervals between transfers under their conditions used for storage. Such studies would involve performing subcultures at scheduled times until the laboratory identifies an acceptable interval between transfers at which a microorganism can reliably and reproducibly be recovered. When transfers are performed, 5 to 10 representative colonies should be used to avoid the possibility of introducing an altered genotypic or phenotypic characteristic. For the passage and storage of quality control organisms for antimicrobial susceptibility testing, published standards should be followed (10).

sect3.title: Quality Control Procedures
sect3.para: Although it is not necessary with each transfer, the status of the isolate should be assessed periodically. Ongoing viability, stability of phenotype, microorganism identity, and the rate of contamination of stored isolates should be determined and documented.

sect2.title: Immersion in Oil
sect2.para: An alternative to capping tubes is to add a layer of mineral oil to the top of the isolate storage medium. Many bacteria and fungi can be stored for periods of up to 2 to 3 years with this method, and transfers are not needed as frequently. However, microorganisms are still metabolically active in this environment, and mutations can still occur. Mineral oil should be medicinal-grade oil with a specific gravity of 0.865 to 0.890. It is important to note that contamination of the isolate storage medium can occur if the mineral oil is not adequately sterilized. For sterilization, it should be heated to 170°C for 1 to 2 h in an oven with proper chemical and biological controls for the sterilization process (4). Laboratories may further consider checking the sterility of the end product by culturing a sample before use. Autoclaving is not considered acceptable because steam cannot penetrate mineral oil as well as it does an aqueous solution. Sterile mineral oil is also commercially available.

To prepare the isolate for stocking, a sampling of 5 to 10 colonies of the microorganism should be placed on an agar slant or in tubed broth media. Once there is adequate growth, typically after 24 to 48 hours of incubation for bacteria and yeast, and ~2 weeks incubation for molds, a layer of mineral oil at least 1 to 2 cm deep is added on top of the slant, and the media must not be exposed to air. As with the simple transfer method, tests for viability should be performed to determine the optimal transfer schedule that will ensure microorganism recovery. Most routine bacteria and nearly all fungi will remain viable for at least 1 to 2 years, with some strains documented to survive for 14 or more years. Colonies may be transferred by first removing as much oil as possible, then sampling colonies on the slant using a sterile stick or needle. Transfers will be less frequent than those of microorganisms stored without oil; however, oil is more difficult to add to vials and to clean up in the event of spills. Oil used to preserve microorganisms should be regarded as contaminated and properly disposed of as biohazardous waste.

sect2.title: Freezing at −20°C
sect2.para: Refrigeration or freezing in ordinary freezers at −20°C may be used to preserve microorganisms for periods longer than those that can be accomplished by repeated transfers. Viability may be maintained for 1 to 2 years for specific microorganisms, but overall, damage caused by ice crystal formation (6) and electrolyte fluctuations (4) results in poor long-term survival. The medium used for storage appears to be important, since preservation times vary from a few months to 2 years depending upon which maintenance medium is used (6, 11, 12) (Table 1). Modern self-defrosting freezers with freeze-thaw cycles must be avoided because cyclic temperature fluctuation will destroy the microorganism. Instead, freezers with only a manual defrosting option should be used.

sect2.title: Drying
sect2.para: Although most microorganisms do not survive drying, molds and some spore-forming bacteria may be dried and stored for prolonged periods. Soil has been described as a storage medium if it is autoclaved and air dried, but it is not a standardized, defined, and consistent product for use over long periods (4). Instead, commercial silica gel can be used in small cotton-plugged tubes after being heated in an oven to 175°C for 1.5 to 2 h, with moderately successful recovery of fungi (6). Alternatively, a suspension of 108 microorganisms can be inoculated onto sterile filter paper strips or disks. The paper is dried in air or under a vacuum and is placed in sterile vials. These vials can be stored in the refrigerator for up to 4 years, and then single strips or disks can be removed as needed (4). This method is commonly used for commercially prepared quality control organisms.

sect2.title: Storage in Distilled Water
sect2.para: Most organisms do poorly in distilled water, but some survive for prolonged periods. In particular, many fungi andPseudomonas spp. can survive for several years in distilled water at room temperature (6, 13). McGinnis et al. found that, with the exception of fungi that do not easily sporulate, 93% of yeasts, molds, and aerobic actinomycetes can be easily and inexpensively preserved this way (14). For bacteria and yeast, a loop full of pure colonies may be transferred to a sterile screw-cap tube containing distilled water and dispersed by mixing. An additional paraffin seal over the screw cap may be used to minimize evaporation (13). There are various methods for storage of fungi in distilled water detailed later in this chapter.

sect2.title: Storage on Swabs
sect2.para: Pure isolates of bacteria can be stored refrigerated for days to weeks if collected on a swab in Amies gel with or without charcoal (15). This is a convenient method of transferring isolates between laboratories. Bacteria collected in this fashion may also be frozen with stability of up to 40 days (16). While formulated as a transport media, liquid Amies, such as used in the ESwab system (Copan Diagnostics, Murietta, CA), can also maintain viability of bacterial and fungal isolates in refrigeration or at room temperature for short-term storage (e.g., 48 hours). Stability may be longer for non-fastidious organisms such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa and storage at –80°C may allow for long-term preservation using liquid Amies (17–19).

sect1.title: Long-Term Preservation Methods
sect1.para: Whereas the methods described above may be used to store microorganisms for periods of up to a few years, ultralow-temperature freezing and freeze-drying (lyophilization) are recommended for long-term storage. Although the initial investment in ultralow-temperature freezers and/or lyophilization may be costly, these methods are less labor-intensive over time, require less laboratory space (e.g., a cryovial versus broth or agar media), and reduce the chance of mutation events. Of course, mutations, loss of mobile genetic elements, or phenotypic changes can still occur. For example,Staphylococcus aureus strains were observed to lose the mecA gene during long-term preservation at −80°C (20), and Streptococcus pneumoniae has been described to become optochin resistant after frozen storage in glycerol (21). Similar to other preservation methods, survival rates after freeze-drying vary with species. Evaluating microorganisms over a 10-year period, Miyamoto-Shinohara et al. found that survival rates after freeze-drying for Brevibacterium spp. and Corynebacterium spp. approached 80%, whereas those for Streptococcus mutans decreased to 20% after 10 years (22).

sect2.title: Ultralow-Temperature Freezing
sect2.para: Microorganisms can be maintained at temperatures of −70°C or lower for prolonged periods. Systems for achieving these temperatures include ultralow-temperature electric freezers and liquid nitrogen storage units. With either system, unwanted heating can occur due to the loss of electrical power or liquid nitrogen. Close observation of the system and an adequate alarm mechanism are essential, since any increase in temperature will reduce organism viability. If the temperature does rise, restoring power and returning to the target storage temperature as quickly as possible are essential. The presence of a cryopreservative such as glycerol or skim milk may reduce the risk to microorganisms upon exposure to higher temperatures (23, 24). If thawing does occur, there are no guidelines for rapid restoration of the storage condition. Refreezing of the sealed vials as described below may be considered.

For long-term storage, temperatures below −130°C are recommended for fastidious cells, particularly fungal hyphae, spirochetes, and protozoa. Cellular activity and chemical reactions cease at these low temperatures, but at −70°C they may still continue to a limited extent along with gradual decline in viability. Hence, for long-term cryopreservation of organisms beyond 10 to 15 years, storage in liquid nitrogen (−196°C) or liquid nitrogen vapor (−150°C) is recommended (3).

sect3.title: Storage Vials
sect3.para: Storage vials must be able to withstand very low temperatures and maintain a seal for their contents. Plastic (polypropylene) or glass (borosilicate) tubes that have been sterilized may be used. Plastic vials with screw tops and silicone washers are much easier to use than glass vials that must be sealed with a flame and then scored and broken open. Several commercial suppliers stock acceptable vials, e.g., Thermo Fisher Scientific (Waltham, MA), VWR Scientific (Radnor, PA), DWK Life Sciences (Millville, NJ), and Becton, Dickinson and Co. (Franklin Lakes, NJ). Vials come in a variety of sizes. Half-dram vials are available from several suppliers and can be conveniently packaged in a 12-by-12 grid so that 144 vials are stored in one box or layer.

sect3.title: Cryoprotective Agents
sect3.para: To protect microorganisms from damage during the freezing process, during storage, and during thawing, cryoprotective agents are often added to the culture suspension. Whereas most bacteria, fungi, and viruses survive better with such additives, studies have shown that cryoprotective agents significantly damage other organisms. The reader is referred to detailed references for specifics (3, 6). Rapid freezing without additives may still be acceptable for the long-term survival of protozoa, although freeze-drying may be preferred.

There are two types of cryoprotective agents: those that enter the cell and protect the intracellular environment and others that protect the external milieu of the organism. Glycerol and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) are usually used for the former; sucrose, lactose, glucose, mannitol, sorbitol, dextran, polyvinylpyrrolidone, polyglycol, and skim milk are used for the latter. Combinations of agents as well as detergents (e.g., Tween 80 and Triton WR 1339), other carbohydrates (e.g., honey), and calcium lactobionate have also been used. The most universal cryoprotectant is DMSO; however, the optimal cryoprotectant often varies with the microorganism. For example, glycerol appears to be best suited for the general preservation of bacteria and fungi whereas DMSO is preferred for complex organism cells such as protozoa and algae (3). A comprehensive review of protectant additives used in the cryopreservation of microorganisms is provided by Hubálek (25).

Glycerol is typically added at a final concentration of 10% (vol/vol), and DMSO is added at 5% (vol/vol). Prior to use, glycerol is sterilized by autoclaving. Once prepared, it can be stocked at room temperature for months. DMSO must be filter sterilized and can be stored in open containers for only 1 month prior to use.

Of the external products, skim milk is the most often used. Dehydrated skim milk can be purchased from medical product suppliers, e.g., Becton, Dickinson and Co. and Hardy Diagnostics (Santa Maria, CA). It is autoclaved and used in a final concentration of 20% (wt/vol) in distilled water (3). This is double the concentration of a reconstituted equivalent of regular milk.

sect3.title: Preparation of Microorganisms for Freezing
sect3.para: Microorganisms are inoculated into a medium that adequately supports maximal growth. Cultures are allowed to mature to the late growth or stationary phase before being harvested. Typically, broth specimens are centrifuged to create a pellet of microorganisms. The pellet is withdrawn and resuspended in 2 to 5 ml of broth with the appropriate concentration of cryoprotectant additive. For microorganisms growing on agar, the agar surface can be scraped with a sterile loop, which is then placed directly into the vial of cryoprotectant and emulsified into a final dense suspension. The volume of the aliquots to be frozen is typically 0.2 to 2.0 ml. While more prone to contamination, another approach is to place broth containing the cryoprotectant on the surface of the agar. The surface is scraped with a pipette or sterile loop to suspend microorganisms, and then the broth mixture is pipetted directly into freezer vials.

sect3.title: Freezing Method
sect3.para: The American Type Culture Collection (ATCC) recommends slow, controlled-rate freezing at a 1°C decrease per minute until the vials cool to a temperature of at least −30°C, followed by more rapid cooling until the final storage temperature is achieved (3). This protocol is best achieved using a controlled-rate freezer. As an alternative, the ATCC suggests the use of an insulated freezing chamber, such as one commercially available (e.g., CoolCell LX, ATCC ACS-6000), or simply an appropriate polystyrene box (15-mm-thick sides and 1-liter capacity) packed with insulating materials. Studies in the 1970s showed that uncontrolled-rate freezing may be acceptable for most organisms and is much less expensive and labor-intensive (6). When organisms are stored in liquid nitrogen, however, it is still recommended that vials be placed initially in a −60°C freezer for 1 h and then transferred into the liquid nitrogen. When organisms are stored permanently at −60 to −70°C, the vials can be placed directly into the freezer (3, 6).

Vials with small glass beads or plastic beads can also be used for freezing bacteria, e.g., CRYOBANK (Copan Diagnostics) or Microbank (Pro-Lab Diagnostics, Round Rock, TX) systems. The culture suspension coats the beads, and then the excess culture suspension is aspirated from the vial. Individual beads can then be removed from storage for reconstitution without thawing the entire sample. These beads are optimized for bacterial storage (26), but manufacturer information is available (Pro-Lab Diagnostics) should frozen storage of fungal spores be attempted.

sect3.title: Thawing
sect3.para: Damage to microorganisms occurs as they are warmed from the frozen state. Critical temperatures appear to be between −40 and −5°C. Studies suggest that rapid warming through these temperatures improves recovery rates. For optimal results, stored culture vials should be warmed rapidly in a 35°C water bath until all ice has disappeared (3, 6). Once a vial is thawed, the organism should be transferred to an appropriate growth medium immediately. Great care must be exercised during the thawing phase, since rapid temperature changes and resulting air pressure changes inside vials can cause the vials to explode. Protective clothing and eyewear must be worn during this process.

For most practical purposes in the clinical laboratory, however, thorough thawing of stored bacteria or yeast in a water bath is not practical or necessary. In our experience, the frozen vial can be thawed at room temperature and plated with good results for most routine organisms. If the organism vial must be saved for reuse at a later date, one may scrape off a small portion of the frozen contents with a sterile loop or pipette tip and then inoculate the appropriate media. The vial may be returned to frozen storage immediately without thawing and with limited damage to the organism.

sect3.title: Specialized Storage Systems
sect3.para: Computerized technology can facilitate the organization and database management of large storage collections. Some laboratories have developed their own tracking system, while other products are commercially available, for example, Freezerworks (Dataworks Development, Inc., Mountlake Terrace, WA) and FreezerPro (Ruro Inc., Frederick, MD). These kinds of software allow the user to enter data for each isolate in the repository, and the data are stored in a highly organized, searchable fashion. Radio-frequency identification labeling may also be used for compact storage of information associated with each isolate, for example, ColdTrack vials (BioTillion LLC, Skillman, NJ) and FreezerPro radio-frequency identification kits. Aside from storage location, it would be helpful to maintain data in such tracking systems for clinical isolates that include isolate identifiers, date of collection, specimen source, organism identification, and antimicrobial susceptibility data, if applicable. Many modern laboratory information systems have storage tracking functionality in which data on the specific storage location, such as rack number and position coordinates, may be entered for each isolate, to be queried or utilized downstream.

sect2.title: Freeze-Drying (Lyophilization)
sect2.para: Freeze-drying is considered to be the most effective way to provide long-term storage of most bacteria, yeasts, sporulating molds, and viruses. Better preservation occurs with freeze-drying than with other methods because freeze-drying reduces the risk of intracellular ice crystallization, which compromises viability. Removal of water from the isolate effectively prevents this damage. Among bacteria, the relative viability with lyophilization is greatest with Gram-positive bacteria (sporeformers in particular) and decreases with Gram-negative bacteria (6, 27), but overall, the viability of bacteria can be maintained for as long as 30 years. In addition, large numbers of vials of dried microorganisms can be stored with limited space, and organisms can be easily transported long distances at room temperature.

The process combines freezing and dehydration. Organisms are initially frozen and then dried by lowering the atmospheric pressure with a vacuum apparatus. Freeze-drying has been extensively reviewed elsewhere (5), and the required equipment includes a vacuum pump connected in line to a condenser and to the specimens. Specimens can be connected individually to the condenser (manifold method) or can be placed in a chamber where they are dehydrated in one larger air space (chamber or batch method). Alexander et al. and Heckly have both published detailed descriptions of equipment options (3, 5).

sect3.title: Storage Vials
sect3.para: Glass vials are used for all freeze-dried specimens. When freeze-drying is performed in a chamber, double glass vials are used. In the chamber method, an outer soft-glass vial is added for protection and preservation of the dehydrated specimen. Silica gel granules are placed in the bottom of the outer vial before the inner vial is inserted and cushioned with cotton. For the manifold method, a single glass vial is used. For both methods, the vial containing the actual specimen is lightly plugged with absorbent cotton. The storage vial in the manifold method or the outer vial in the chamber method must be sealed to maintain the vacuum and the dry atmospheric condition. All vials are sterilized prior to use by heating in a hot-air oven (5).

sect3.title: Cryoprotective Agents
sect3.para: Research concerning cryoprotective agents has been extensively reviewed (5). The two most commonly used agents are skim milk and sucrose. Skim milk is usually used for chamber lyophilization, and sucrose is usually used for manifold lyophilization. Skim milk is prepared by making a 20% (vol/vol) solution of skim milk in distilled water. The solution is divided into 5-ml aliquots and autoclaved at 116°C, with care taken to prevent overheating and caramelization of the solution. The preparation is then used in smaller volumes as described above for freezing. Sucrose is prepared in an initial mixture of 24% (vol/vol) sucrose in water and added in equal volumes to the microorganism suspension in growth medium to make a final concentration of 12% (vol/vol).

sect3.title: Preparation of Microorganisms for Lyophilization
sect3.para: As with simple freezing, maximum recovery of organisms is achieved by using microorganisms in the late growth or stationary phase from the growth of an inoculum in an appropriate solid or liquid growth medium (refer to “Preparation of Microorganisms for Freezing,” above). There should be a high starting concentration of microorganisms. The ATCC recommends a concentration of at least 108 CFU/ml (3), whereas Heckly suggests a concentration of 1010 CFU/ml or higher (5).

sect3.title: Freeze-Drying Methods
sect3.para: In the chamber method, inner vials with the microorganism suspension are placed in a single layer inside a stainless-steel container. This container is placed in a low-temperature freezer at −60°C for 1 h. The container is then transferred to a chamber containing a low-temperature bath, e.g., dry ice in ethyl cellosolve (2-ethoxyethanol) or another solvent, and covered with a sealable vacuum top, which is connected in sequence to a condenser reservoir also filled with the dry ice-solvent mixture and to a vacuum pump. The vacuum is maintained at a minimum of 30 μm Hg for 18 h. At the same time, the outer vials are prepared by being heated in an oven overnight, filled with silica gel granules and cotton, and placed in a dry cabinet with <10% relative humidity. The freeze-dried inner vials are inserted into the outer vials, and the outer vials are heat sealed. Multiple different strains or species should probably not be processed in the same batch. Cross-contamination rates vary from 0.8 to 3.3% when two different microorganisms are placed on opposite sides of the same container and are as high as 8.3 to 13.3% when microorganisms are intermingled (28).

In the manifold method, a rack of individual vials is used rather than a single container. The rack is placed in a dry ice bath. After the freezing process, the vials are connected by individual rubber tubes in sequence to the condenser container filled with the dry ice-solvent mixture and to the vacuum pump. As in the method described above, the vacuum is maintained at 30 μm Hg for 18 h and then the individual vials are sealed.

sect3.title: Storage
sect3.para: Individual vials need to be appropriately labeled and stored. Storage at room temperature does not maintain viability and is not recommended. Storage at 4°C in an ordinary refrigerator is acceptable, but survival rates may be improved at temperatures of −30 to −60°C (3, 5).

sect3.title: Reconstitution
sect3.para: Care must be taken when opening vials for reconstitution because of the vacuum inside the vial. Safety glasses should always be worn, and vials should be covered with gauze to prevent injury if the vial explodes when air rushes in. Reconstitution should also be conducted in a closed hood to avoid dispersal of microorganisms. The surface of the vial should be wiped with 70% alcohol, and then the top of the glass vial can be scored and broken off or punctured with a hot needle. A small amount (0.1 to 0.4 ml) of growth medium is injected into the vial with a needle and syringe or a Pasteur pipette, the contents are stirred until the isolate is fully suspended, and then the entire contents are transferred with the same syringe or pipette to appropriate broth or agar media. A purity check must be done on each isolate because of the possibility of either cross-contamination or mutation during the preservation process (3, 5).

sect2.title: PROCEDURES FOR SPECIFIC ORGANISMS
sect2.para: Procedures for specific organisms are described below and summarized inTable 1.

sect1.title: Bacteria
sect1.para: All of the material presented in this chapter applies primarily to the preservation of bacteria. Simple transfer, storage under mineral oil, drying, or freezing at −20°C can maintain bacteria for short periods; freezing in ultralow-temperature electric freezers at −70°C or in liquid nitrogen at −196°C or freeze-drying can provide long-term preservation. A summary of the studies of bacterial preservation has been published (6). In general, serial transfer will preserve bacteria for up to a few months, storage under mineral oil or with drying will last 1 to 2 years, freezing at −20°C will preserve bacteria for 1 to 3 years, freezing at −70°C will preserve bacteria for 1 to 10 years, and freezing in liquid nitrogen and freeze-drying will preserve bacteria for up to 30 years (4). Stock cultures of quality control microorganisms can be maintained in a cryopreservative suspension for up to 1 year at −20°C or indefinitely at −70°C. For fastidious bacteria such as S. pneumoniae, Neisseria spp., and Haemophilus spp., the optimal methods are lyophilization and freezing at −70°C using Trypticase soy broth with glycerol as a preservation medium (29–31). More recently, a simple method of saturating cotton swabs with cultured isolates of Neisseria and Haemophilus spp. and storing them in cryovials at –80°C was found to retain organism viability for at least 8 years (32).

For plasmid-containing bacteria, there is plasmid degradation over time that varies with the microorganism and the storage method (33, 34). For clinical microbiology laboratories, the main concern with plasmid stability usually relates to maintaining the reproducibility of antimicrobial susceptibility testing phenotype. For long-term storage of quality control organisms with plasmid-mediated mechanisms of resistance, the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) recommends storage at <–60°C (35).

sect1.title: Protozoa
sect1.para: Information concerning the preservation of protozoa is limited, in keeping with the infrequent need for such a process in clinical microbiology laboratories. Variable methods for individual genera have been described. In general, freezing appears to be preferred to freeze-drying. Storage in liquid nitrogen is recommended for many of the protozoa discussed below, although cryopreservation up to several months may be successful at −70°C (36). Cryopreservation of other parasites such as helminths is rarely done in clinical laboratories, and methods for storing and preserving viability for various parasites are reviewed elsewhere (36). All of the following procedures are as described by the ATCC (3) and supplemented with more recent studies.

Acanthamoeba spp., Leishmania spp., Naegleria spp., Trichomonas spp., and Trypanosoma spp. can be handled as described above for ultralow-temperature freezing with 5% (vol/vol) DMSO as the cryoprotective agent. These organisms should be stored in liquid nitrogen.

Acanthamoeba spp. and Naegleria spp. can also be dried on filter paper at room temperature. Aliquots of a microorganism suspension (0.3 ml) are pipetted onto the paper in a shell vial and dried in air for 14 days at room temperature and then in a vacuum desiccator for an additional week. The vials are sealed and stored in liquid nitrogen.

Entamoeba spp. can be stored frozen at −40°C suspended in a mixture of growth medium containing 12% (vol/vol) DMSO and 6% (vol/vol) sucrose (3). Others have reported some success with preserving these organisms in 5 to 10% DMSO at −70°C or in liquid nitrogen (37, 38).

Leishmania spp. may be prepared by inoculation of the organism into an animal host. At the peak of infection, the spleen is harvested and homogenized in half the final volume of ATCC medium 811 salt solution. Freezing is completed with 10% glycerol as the cryoprotectant. For Leishmania promastigotes that have been cultivated in tubes of Novy-MacNeal-Nicolle medium, successful storage up to 4 months is possible by directly freezing the tubes at −80°C (39). Others have shown that organisms can remain viable for at least 7 months if refrigerated after subculture to slants of rabbit blood agar (40).

Plasmodium spp. can be stored from infected blood samples. At the height of parasitemia, blood is obtained and anticoagulated with the following preparation: 1.33 g of sodium citrate, 0.47 g of citric acid, 3.00 g of dextrose, 200 mg of heparin (sodium), and 100 ml of distilled water. The final concentration of anticoagulant added to blood is 10%. To this anticoagulated blood, 30% glycerol in 0.0667 M phosphate buffer is added to a final concentration of 10% (vol/vol) glycerol. Frozen storage is optimal in liquid nitrogen.

Trypanosoma spp. grown from an animal host are harvested at the peak of parasitemia. Blood is drawn into heparinized tubes and diluted 1:1 in Tyrode’s solution (per liter: 8.0 g of NaCl, 0.02 g of KCl, 0.2 g of CaCl2, 0.1 g of MgCl2, 0.05 g of NaH2PO4, 1.0 g of NaHCO3, and 1.0 g of glucose) with 1 to 5% phenol red added. Then 5% DMSO is added as the cryoprotectant, and the specimen is stored in liquid nitrogen. Alternatively, 10 to 50% glycerol can be used as the cryoprotectant. Trypanosomes grown axenically may also be preserved with either cryoprotectant. Notably, the trypanosomes are relatively resilient to different rates of cooling during the freezing process (37).

sect1.title: Yeasts and Filamentous Fungi
sect1.para: All of the techniques described above have been applied to the storage of yeasts and fungi (4, 6, 7, 41). The individual method employed depends on the species to be preserved and whether or not it sporulates.

sect2.title: Subculturing
sect2.para: Subculturing is the simplest method of maintaining living fungi and involves serial transfer to fresh solid or liquid media. Storage is accomplished usually at room or refrigerator temperature. Fungi may be maintained by subculturing for a number of years. Care must be taken to avoid aerosolization and contamination of the laboratory or other specimens, with all work being conducted in a biosafety cabinet.

sect2.title: Storage Under Oil
sect2.para: Whereas species ofAspergillus and Penicillium have remained viable under oil for 40 years (7), many other genera have shown deterioration after 1 to 2 years and must be transferred periodically.

sect2.title: Water Storage
sect2.para: Many fungi can be stored successfully for prolonged periods in distilled water (13, 42). A simple method is to pipette 6 to 7 ml of sterile distilled water onto 2-week-old culture slants in screw-cap tubes. The spores and fragments of hyphae are dislodged by scraping with a pipette, and the suspension is transferred to a sterile screw-top vial, which is tightly capped and stored at 25°C. Fungi are revived by subculturing 0.2 to 0.3 ml of the suspension to appropriate media (43).

An alternative method is to cut agar blocks from the growing edge of a fungal colony and place them in sterile distilled water in bottles with screw-cap lids (44). The cultures are stored at 20 to 25°C. The fungi are retrieved by removing a block and placing it mycelium side down on growth medium appropriate for that species (7). Contamination (22.8%) is a significant problem with this method (44).

sect2.title: Drying
sect2.para: Dry storage of organisms on sterile filter paper has been used for fungi. Only 6 of 16 genera of fungi stored in this fashion survived for 4 years (45). The greatest success with dry storage of fungi was reported for sporulating fungi stored in silica gel or in soil (7).

sect2.title: Freezing
sect2.para: Fungi have been successfully preserved by storage in liquid nitrogen by using glycerol or DMSO as a cryopreservative. Yeasts may also be stored at ultralow temperatures in skim milk. Broth cultures may be disrupted in a Waring blender and suspended in equal parts of DMSO or glycerol to achieve final concentrations of 5 or 10%, respectively. Overt pathogens should not be disrupted in a mechanical blender because of the potential biohazard associated with aerosolization.Histoplasma, Paracoccidioides, and Blastomyces species should be frozen in the yeast phase, and Coccidioides species should be frozen in the early mycelial phase to minimize exposure of laboratory personnel. Otherwise, procedures for freezing are as described above.

sect2.title: Freeze-Drying
sect2.para: Most spore-forming fungi can be preserved by freeze-drying. Cultures to be stored by freeze-drying should be grown on agar or broth medium to the point of maximum sporulation (3) and processed as described above. Survival in storage for many years has been demonstrated (46, 47), but this is true only for sporulating organisms. Young vegetative hyphae of fungi do not survive freeze-drying (7).

sect1.title: Viruses
sect1.para: Ultralow-temperature freezing is generally effective for storing viruses. Glycerol and DMSO may be used as cryoprotectants as described above. For most viruses isolated in clinical laboratories, virus supernatant from infected cell cultures may be directly frozen, particularly if the culture medium contains animal serum, which can serve as a cryoprotectant. Other cryoprotectants, such as sucrose-phosphate-glutamate containing 1% bovine albumin and hypertonic sucrose, are particularly effective, the latter for storing labile viruses such as respiratory syncytial virus (6, 48, 49). If ultralow-temperature freezing is employed, the rate of freezing should be as high as possible, using small-volume suspensions (0.1 to 0.5 ml). In addition to freezing pure isolates, stool specimens known to contain viral enteric pathogens have been maintained at −70 to −85°C for 6 to 10 years with reasonable recovery and no change in the morphological characteristics of astroviruses, small round structured viruses, enteric adenoviruses, rotaviruses, and caliciviruses (50).

Gallo et al. evaluated five types of media for storage of HIV-infected peripheral blood lymphocytes and concluded that freezing peripheral blood lymphocytes in RPMI 1640 containing 10% fetal bovine serum and 10% DMSO and storing them at −60°C is acceptable for HIV isolation (51).

Freeze-drying is probably the optimal method for preserving viruses for extended periods. A detailed review of acceptable procedures has been published (52). Virus suspensions freeze-dried in medium supported with sucrose-phosphate-glutamate containing 1% bovine albumin appear to survive better (6, 53). Lyophilization of polioviruses and other enteroviruses works best when electrolytes are removed by dialysis or ultrafiltration (6).

While viral culture of SARS-CoV-2 is not usually performed in clinical laboratories, protocols exist for harvesting and storage of viral isolates and are similar to the approaches described above (54, 55). As with other novel respiratory viruses, handling of SARS-CoV-2 cultures must be done in a biosafety level 3 laboratory in accordance with regulatory guidance.

sect1.title: Select Agents
sect1.para: In response to the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002, federal regulations require laboratories that store select agents to register and comply with the standards established by the act (56). A current and complete list of microorganisms considered to be select agents can be found at http://www.selectagents.gov. Regardless of the method for long-term preservation, laboratories must register with the Federal Select Agent Program if they wish to use, possess, or transfer select agents or toxins. To minimize the risk to public health and safety, select agents must be stored in a highly secured area with restricted access and appropriate safeguards. Only registered individuals who have completed training for handling select agents can access and retrieve these microorganisms from storage. An accurate and current inventory of select agents held in long-term storage must be maintained. Further guidance on storing select agents is available from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (https://www.selectagents.gov/ig-criteria.html).

sect2.title: STORAGE OF NUCLEIC ACIDS
sect2.para: The long-term preservation methods described above are specifically designed for the recovery of microorganisms for further cultivation. With molecular testing implemented in many clinical microbiology laboratories, it has become increasingly important to understand the storage conditions required for microorganism nucleic acids. Studies of extracted DNA from various specimen types have shown that microbial DNA is stable at refrigerated temperatures for at least 1 year and at frozen temperatures –20°C and below for 7 or more years (57, 58). Extracted DNA is typically stored in standard Tris-EDTA, which serves as a slightly basic buffer and preservative (57). RNA, as a more labile molecule that is susceptible to degradation by ubiquitous ribonucleases, is best stored at –70°C or below. Extracted RNA may be stored in ethanol as a precipitate, or in Tris-EDTA (ideally pH 7 to 7.4) or other, commercially available RNA storage solutions (57). Care must be taken in handling extracted RNA, with gloved hands and using storage vials and solutions that are RNAse free (57, 59). Multiple freeze-thaw cycles of extracted nucleic acid should be avoided.

sect2.title: STORAGE OF PATIENT SPECIMENS FOR VERIFICATION STUDIES
sect2.para: Archiving of patient specimens containing analytes of interest helps clinical laboratories prepare for future lot-to-lot comparisons, quality control needs, and new assay verification studies. While contrived specimens and control materials are often used for verification of assays including multiplexed molecular panels, inclusion of primary patient specimens provides additional assurance that the assay can reliably detect target pathogens in a true biological matrix. Clinical laboratories should also consider how to properly store specimens that have unusual findings, that may be of public health interest, or that may require additional investigation. Given the competing storage needs of a laboratory, transfer of specimens to smaller vials is often necessary to conserve space. On the other hand, it may be advisable to make several single-use aliquots of specimens with rare or unusual analytes to prevent multiple freeze-thaw cycles to the specimen. In all cases, samples must be properly labeled and stored in an organized fashion, and inventory must be regularly updated for both practical and biosafety reasons.

Manufacturer’s product inserts outline specimen stability limits for specific assays and provide data describing comparative fresh-frozen equivalency studies, if performed. Such information is useful for defining short-term storage parameters and for gauging reasonable performance expectations for using archived specimens as part of the laboratory’s quality management program. Additional guidance on generally known stability limits for specimens in long-term storage is given below.

To preserve specimens containing microorganism DNA or RNA of interest, a simple and inexpensive method for blood or plasma is to spot the specimen on a filter paper-based product such as Whatman Flinders Technology Associates (FTA) matrix cards (Whatman International Ltd., Maidstone, United Kingdom) (60, 61). This approach is useful in settings where refrigerators and freezers are not readily available. In laboratories with access to ultralow freezer storage, microbial nucleic acids in patient specimens should be archived at –70°C or lower, temperatures which preserve not only the nucleic acid but often organism viability within the primary specimen (62). Refrigerated storage and storage at –20°C can result in decay of nucleic acid target quantities, with variable results depending on the study, pathogen target, and length of storage time (63–65). Multiple freeze-thaw cycles should also be avoided, although the nucleic acid content of some microbes can tolerate numerous freeze-thaws (59, 66).

Stool specimens containing gastrointestinal pathogens of interest may be stored frozen in Cary-Blair transport medium or without preservatives with generally good recovery of pathogen nucleic acid for molecular detection. For respiratory specimens collected in media such as universal transport media, viral transport media, or M4, storage at or below –70°C preserves respiratory virus and atypical bacteria for molecular detection and culture recovery for years (48, 59). The integrity of anticoagulated whole blood or plasma and unpreserved cerebrospinal, urine, serum, and other body fluids for molecular testing is also expected to be maintained intact at –70°C or below. This includes positive blood culture broths that have recovered bloodstream pathogens of interest, which may be useful to a biobank for evaluation of molecular blood pathogen panels.

Specimens containing antibodies of interest typically retain stability for long periods when stored at –20°C or lower. Antibodies are considered relatively stable molecules at refrigerated temperatures, but the activity of proteases found in biological specimens is minimized at lower temperatures (69–71). As demonstrated during the SARS-CoV-2 pandemic, banked pre-2019 serum or plasma as well as prospectively collected serum or plasma from patients in the acute and convalescent phase of SARS-CoV-2 infection were necessary planning steps for clinical laboratories to evaluate new assays for detecting SARS-CoV-2 antibodies (72). Preservation of microbial antigens in a specimen, in contrast to antibodies, is less predictable at room and refrigerated temperatures. Stability is affected by pH, temperature, and presence of proteases, among other biological factors (73). Some antigens such as cryptococcal polysaccharide antigen may be stable in specimens stored at –20°C or below (74). Regardless, as a general rule, biological specimens should be held at –70°C or colder for optimal preservation of pathogenic antigens (75–78).

sect1.title: Preservation of Specimen Microbiome
sect1.para: Preservation of the microbial communities in clinical specimens, such as feces, vaginal samples, and sputa, is of great importance to current translational research efforts and potentially to future clinical testing. It is possible to preserve the microbiota composition and the metabolic profile of fecal specimens with addition of 5% DMSO and storage at −80°C for up to 3 months (79). If the intent is to preserve DNA content rather than cell viability, frozen storage with a cryoprotectant is not necessary. Other fixatives have been used for this application, including 70% ethanol and commercial products such as DNA/RNA Shield (Zymo Research, Irvine, CA), OMNIgene kits (DNA Genotek, Kanata, Ontario, Canada), and RNAlater (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Walthan, MA) (80, 81). When nucleic acid extraction cannot be performed promptly, fecal contents appear to remain stable for up to 24 h at room temperature and for at least 6 months at −80°C (82). One reported method to homogenize fecal samples for improved sampling involves grinding the specimen to a fine powder with a mortar and pestle in liquid nitrogen, then aliquoting it for storage at −80°C (83). RNA preservatives may be used for short-term storage at room temperature but are generally not recommended for frozen specimen storage because they may decrease DNA yield and apparent abundance of different taxa (83). The bacterial composition and metabolic profiles of vaginal and sputum samples have also been found to remain stable for weeks when stored frozen at −20°C or −80°C (84–86). For sputum samples, storage at −80°C within 12 h of specimen collection has been recommended for optimal results (87). Freeze-thawing has been shown to have detrimental effects on microbial composition of fecal and sputum samples after ≥4 cycles (83, 85). Clinical samples may also be stable when first stored at −20°C and then transferred to −80°C (84, 88). Specimen collection could also be coupled with long-term frozen storage by directly collecting a swab into liquid Amies medium supplemented with 20% glycerol or with commercially available products such as eNAT collection kit (Copan Diagnostics, Murrieta, CA).

sect2.title: DISASTER PREPAREDNESS
sect2.para: Especially in light of natural disasters such as Hurricanes Katrina and Sandy, laboratories should consider the value of their organism collection and have a written emergency plan for the biorepository (89). For valuable or large collections of microorganisms in long-term storage, the International Society for Biological and Environmental Repositories provides guidance on emergency preparedness (http://www.isber.org). It is good practice to maintain backup copies of written or electronic data linked to the stored organisms. A laboratory may consider dividing irretrievable collections of microorganisms between containers or laboratory locations if these options are feasible. Liquid nitrogen storage containers do not require constant electrical power for operation. They may be filled up prior to an anticipated evacuation to maximize their temperature stability. For electric-powered freezers, laboratories should consider connection to a backup energy source such as an uninterruptable power supply or motor generator.

sect2.title: FUTURE DIRECTIONS
sect2.para: The field of microbiology continues to rapidly evolve in this era of genomics, transcriptomics, and proteomics. Scientific research in human genetics, health care epidemiology, global health, antimicrobial resistance, microbial taxonomy, and infectious diseases relies heavily upon carefully curated repositories of microorganisms. Clinical laboratories have various levels of resources for the preservation of microorganisms and their long-term storage, but anyone can contribute to national or international culture collections. Additionally, scientific advancements of pathogen discovery, genomics, and proteomics are supported by collecting and storing biological specimens such as human blood and urine, particularly from patients with noncultivable pathogens or ill-defined clinical syndromes. Scientific protocols have been developed to preserve the integrity of these biological specimens for long-term storage, up to 30 years (73, 89). All should partner with the scientific community (e.g., regional research centers of excellence or government-sponsored projects) by contributing to both specimen and microorganism repositories. The answers to many future questions lie in our clinical laboratories of today.
